answer_html: The constraint on \(b_1, b_2, b_3\) is the equation \(-2b_1 + b_2 -b_3 = 0\).
answer_latex:
The constraint on $b_1, b_2, b_3$ is the equation
$-2b_1 + b_2 -b_3 = 0$.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
To find the condition on \(b_1, b_2, b_3\), let us first solve the matrix problem \(Ax = b\).

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1& 0 & 2 & 3& | & b_1\\ 2& 1 & 8 & 8& | & b_2\\ 0& 1 & 4 &2 & | & b_3 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 &0 \\ {\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{1}}\\{\color{Red}{0}}&{\color{Red}{ 1}} & {\color{Red}{0}} \end{bmatrix}\)

\(L = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0& 1 & 0\\ {\color{Green}{2}}&{\color{Purple}{1}} & 1\end{bmatrix}\)

Since we are given the LU decomposition and partial pivoting of matrix A, we can simply follow the steps described by the matrix P (swapping the second and third row which is highlighted in \({\color{Red}{red}}\))and L (subtracting twice the first row (\({\color{Green}{green}}\)) from the third row and subtracting once the second row from the third row(\({\color{Purple}{purple}}\))), we would arrive at

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 2 & 3 & | & b_1\\ 0 & 1 & 4 & 2 & | & b_3\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & | & b_2 - b_3 - 2b_1 \end{bmatrix}\)

In order for \(Ax = b\) to have at least solution, the above matrix must be consistent, therefore the last row must contain all zeros.

The constraint on \(b_1, b_2, b_3\) is the equation \(-2b_1 + b_2 -b_3 = 0\).
sols_latex:
To find the condition on $b_1, b_2, b_3$, let us first solve the matrix
problem $Ax = b$.

$\begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 & 2 & 3& | & b_1\\
2& 1 & 8 & 8& | & b_2\\
0& 1 & 4 &2 & | & b_3
\end{bmatrix}$

$P = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 &0 \\
{\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{1}}\\{\color{Red}{0}}&{\color{Red}{ 1}} & {\color{Red}{0}}
\end{bmatrix}$

$L = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0\\
0& 1 & 0\\
{\color{Green}{2}}&{\color{Purple}{1}} & 1\end{bmatrix}$

Since we are given the LU decomposition and partial pivoting of matrix
A, we can simply follow the steps described by the matrix P (swapping
the second and third row which is highlighted in ${\color{Red}{red}}$)and L (subtracting twice the first row (${\color{Green}{green}}$) from
the third row and subtracting once the second row from the third
row(${\color{Purple}{purple}}$)), we would arrive at

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 2 & 3 & | & b_1\\
0 & 1 & 4 & 2 & | & b_3\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & | & b_2 - b_3 - 2b_1
\end{bmatrix}$

In order for $Ax = b$ to have at least solution, the above matrix must
be consistent, therefore the last row must contain all zeros.

The constraint on $b_1, b_2, b_3$ is the equation
$-2b_1 + b_2 -b_3 = 0$.
sols_raw:
To find the condition on <math>b_1, b_2, b_3</math>, let us first solve the matrix problem <math>Ax = b</math>.

<math>\begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 & 2 & 3& | & b_1\\
2& 1 & 8 & 8& | & b_2\\
0& 1 & 4 &2 & | & b_3
\end{bmatrix}</math>

<math>P = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 &0 \\
{\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{1}}\\
{\color{Red}{0}}&{\color{Red}{ 1}} & {\color{Red}{0}}
\end{bmatrix}</math>

<math>L = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0\\
0& 1 & 0\\
{\color{Green}{2}}&{\color{Purple}{1}} & 1
\end{bmatrix}</math>

Since we are given the LU decomposition and partial pivoting of matrix A, we can simply follow the steps described by the matrix P (swapping the second and third row which is highlighted in <math>{\color{Red}{red}}</math>) and L (subtracting twice the first row (<math>{\color{Green}{green}}</math>) from the third row and subtracting once the second row from the third row(<math>{\color{Purple}{purple}}</math>)), we would arrive at

<math>\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & 2 & 3 & | & b_1\\
0 & 1 & 4 & 2 & | & b_3\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & | & b_2 - b_3 - 2b_1
\end{bmatrix}</math>

In order for <math>Ax = b</math> to have at least solution, the above matrix must be consistent, therefore the last row must contain all zeros.

The constraint on <math>b_1, b_2, b_3</math> is the equation <math>-2b_1 + b_2 -b_3 = 0</math>.
statement_html:
Let PA = LU be

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 &0 \\ 0& 0 &1 \\ 0& 1 &0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1& 0 &2 &3 \\ 2& 1 & 8 & 8\\ 0& 1& 4 & 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1& 0 &0 \\ 0& 1& 0\\ 2& 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 &2 &3 \\ 0& 1 & 4 &2 \\ 0& 0 &0 &0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} b = \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \\ b_3 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

(b) Find the condition on b1, b2, and b3 so that Ax = b has at least one solution.
statement_raw:
Let ''PA = LU'' be

:<math>\begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &0 \\ 
0& 0 &1 \\ 
0& 1 &0 
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 &2 &3 \\ 
2& 1 & 8 & 8\\ 
0& 1& 4 & 2
\end{bmatrix}
= \begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 &0 \\ 
0& 1& 0\\ 
2& 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &2 &3 \\ 
0& 1 & 4 &2 \\ 
0& 0 &0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}</math>

and

:<math>
b = \begin{bmatrix}
b_1 \\ b_2 \\ b_3
\end{bmatrix}
</math>


'''(b)''' Find the condition on ''b<sub>1</sub>'', ''b<sub>2</sub>'', and ''b<sub>3</sub>'' so that ''Ax = b'' has at least one solution.
